newsitem.title: GERMANY: German shares higher amid post rate-cut aftershock.
newsitem.headline: German shares higher amid post rate-cut aftershock.

text.p: German shares were higher in afternoon trade on Thursday, although traders were still shell-shocked after the Bundesbank's decision to cut its money market rate by 30 basis points.
In late post-bourse trade, the IBIS DAX index stood at 2,564.56 points, up 30.12 points.

"It's hard to know what to make of it really. There are two points of view -- that it's all over, all the expectation is gone, the interest rate cycle is complete, or that there is more room for further cuts," said a London trader.
"I think that the cycle is probably complete," he added.

The Bundesbank cut the securities repurchase rate to a historic low of three percent, a far bigger cut than expected. The cut was interpreted by some as sign that the stint of German rate easing has come to an end.
In the afternoon the market easily digested U.S. jobless figures and took Bundesbank President Hans Tietmeyer's reasons for the repo rate cut very much in its stride.
Tietmeyer said the Bundesbank had decided to cut the repo rate after developments in M3 money supply and inflationary factors and pledged to monitor further developments.
Shares held their gains after the comments.
Shares in the spotlight over the course of the day included BASF AG, which was nearly three percent higher at 43.50 marks in late post-bourse trade.
BASF was boosted by its first half figures, which saw pre-tax profits rise 14.7 percent to 2.32 billion marks.
Builder Hochtief AG was up one mark at 67.50 marks in afternoon trade after its first half results which showed an increase in incoming foreign orders of 191 percent.
Chemical group Merck KGaA fell 1.51 marks to 55.79 after Deutsche Morgan Grenfell lowered its EPS forecasts.
